Title: Linking forum posts -comparch-04-T1.1
Description: The workers will be presented with posts from a forum thread where instructors of a course have replied to student posts. The worker is required to: identify the student post(s) that the instructor’s reply addresses. Instructor's reply post is highlighted

How is multicycle pipeline processor different from unpipelined processor? what i mean to say is if you don't increase the clock frequency (as said in the lecture), the time taken by the instruction to be undergo Fetch, decode and fetch, execute, memory, and \xA0write back stage would still be the same in both multicycle pipeline and unpipelined processor. \xA0 or to say, what is the use of multicycle pipelining against the unpipelined processor when you cannot have multiple instructions in the pipe?

L3S4 explains this rather in depth with diagrams, so I recommend you watch it again if you didn't understand. \xA0However, I will supplement it with the following: The main difference between DRAM and SRAM is the way the data is stored. \xA0 SRAM stores data using two cross-coupled inverters, and is written to by overrdriving the inverters with a new value. \xA0The cross-coupled inverters will hold valid data as long as power is supplied to it. DRAM stores data using a capacitor, and is written to by either charging or discharging the capacitor. \xA0As you may know, capacitors lose their charge based on some time constant. \xA0Thus, the memory cells need to be 'refreshed' (charged or discharged) periodically (on the order of 30 milliseconds). \xA0If one fails to meet the refresh cycle, DRAM does not guarantee the data to be valid. \xA0 DRAM cells are smaller and can be placed closer together, since they are simply a capacitor with one access transistor, leading to rather dense memory arrays. \xA0SRAM cells are larger, the classic SRAM cell contains 6 transistors, and thus, lead to less dense memory arrays. \xA0Therefore, large, slow memory arrays, such as main memory, are typically implemented using DRAM, and small, fast memory arrays, such as caches, are typically implemented using SRAM.

A very good example about computer memory is given in the following link: http://homepage.cs.uri.edu/book/cpu_memory/cpu_memory.htm 'To see how registers, memory, and second storage all work together, let us use the analogy of making a salad. In our kitchen we have: a refrigerator where we store our vegetables for the salad; a counter where we place all of our veggies before putting them on the cutting board for chopping; a cutting board on the counter where we chop the vegetables; a recipe that details what veggies to chop; the corners of the cutting board are kept free for partially chopped piles of veggies that we intend to chop more or to mix with other partially chopped veggies. a bowl on the counter where we mix and store the salad; space in the refrigerator to put the mixed salad after it is made. The process of making the salad is then: bring the veggies from the fridge to the counter top; place some veggies on the chopping board according to the recipe; chop the veggies, possibly storing some partially chopped veggies temporarily on the corners of the cutting board; place all the veggies in the bowl to either put back in the fridge or put directly on the dinner table. The refrigerator is the equivalent of secondary (disk) storage. It can store high volumes of veggies for long periods of time. The counter top is the equivalent of the computer's motherboard - everything is done on the counter (inside the computer). The cutting board is the ALU - the work gets done there. The recipe is the control unit - it tells you what to do on the cutting board (ALU). Space on the counter top is the equivalent of RAM memory - all veggies must be brought from the fridge and placed on the counter top for fast access. Note that the counter top (RAM) is faster to access than the fridge (disk), but cannot hold as much, and cannot hold it for long periods of time. The corners of the cutting board where we temporarily store partially chopped veggies are equivalent to the registers. The corners of the cutting board are very fast to access for chopping, but cannot hold much. The salad bowl is like a temporary register; it is for storing the salad waiting to take back to the fridge (putting data back on a disk) or for taking to the dinner table (outputting the data to an output device).' Hope that helps.

l1/l2 cache's are typically arrays of 6-T/8-T SRAM cells (single port or dual port) and they are clocked at processor freq. Also these SRAMS are high speed low power and are from 3rd part vendors who specialize in the memory design. Where as a register file in a CPU is not a RAM its just an array of FF's to hold on to the values untill the FF's are written to via changing the D input or reading the Q output simultaneously asserting the enable signal to the register being accessed.\xA0 Like someone pointed out in the thread, both run at CPU. Also SRAM's typically support retention (cache state is saved when chip is reset or in hibernation mode please note there are many implementations to cache/processor hibernation this is jsut one of them), this and ECC (error correction which is extremely important for avoid issues like SEU), modern processors like A15 support cache warming wherein caches are preloaded. Register files are just inefficient and donot support efficient random access arch hence them not used for Cache design.
